instructions.preparation: sit back on 45-60 degree incline bench. with arms hanging down straight, position two dumbbells with palms facing inward.
instructions.execution: with elbows back to sides, raise one dumbbell and rotate forearm until forearm is vertical and palm faces shoulder. lower to original position and repeat with opposite arm. continue to alternate between sides.

data.comments: This exercise may be performed by alternating (as described), simultaneous, or in simultaneous-alternating fashion. When elbow is fully flexed, it can travel forward slightly, allowing forearms to be no more than vertical. This additional movement allows for relative release of tension in muscles between repetitions. Also see mechanical analysis of arm curl and question regarding elbow position.

instructions.preparation: sit on seat and grasp handles with underhand grip.
instructions.execution: raise lever on handle until elbow is fully flexed with back of upper arm remaining on pad. lower handle until arm is fully extended. repeat with opposite arm. continue to alternate movement between sides.

data.comments: The biceps may be exercised simultaneous. If machine does not provide support for back of arm, keep elbows from traveling back, particularly during initial flexion. Some machines do not offer adequate resistance at initial range of motion. Consider positioning wrists with slight flexion to compensate.

instructions.preparation: sit on seat and grasp handles with underhand grip.
instructions.execution: raise lever handles until elbows are fully flexed with back of upper arm remaining on pad. lower handles until arm is fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: The biceps may be exercised alternating or simultaneous. If machine does not provide support for back of arm, keep elbows from traveling back, particularly during initial flexion. Some machines do not offer adequate resistance at initial range of motion. Consider positioning wrists with slight flexion to compensate.

instructions.preparation: step up and grasp bar with underhand shoulder width grip.
instructions.execution: pull body up until elbows are to sides. lower body until arms and shoulders are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Easier

instructions.preparation: stand facing arms length away from waist to head height horizontal bar. grasp bar with shoulder width underhand grip. position body under bar with legs, hips and spine straight. arms should be straight, approximately perpendicular to body. heels should make contact with floor with feet about perpendicular to legs.
instructions.execution: keeping body straight, pull body up to bar. return until arms are extended and shoulders are stretched forward. repeat.

data.comments: Bar height can be adjusted to vary resistance. See Gravity Vectors for greater understanding of body angle influences resistance. Also known as Underhand Body Row or Underhand Supine Row.

instructions.preparation: stand at end of wall or in doorway facing perpendicular to wall. position front of straight arm and palm on surface of wall. situate arm around same height of shoulder with elbow positioned away from wall.
instructions.execution: turn body away from positioned arm. hold stretch. repeat with opposite arm.

data.comments: A stationary bar can also be used instead of wall.

instructions.preparation: instruct participant to sit on floor or bench and place arms to behind hips. from behind, grasp participant's wrists, positioning them downward and close together.
instructions.execution: continue to raise participant's arms upward behind their body. hold stretch.

data.comments: Participant's wrists must continue to face downward. See PNF stretch techniques. Also see Seated Biceps Stretch for similar static stretch.

instructions.preparation: sit on floor or mat. lean back and place hands flat on floor close together behind body with fingers positioned away from body.
instructions.execution: scoot hips forward away from hands. hold stretch.

data.comments: Instead of scooting hips forward, hands can be eased backwards.

instructions.preparation: clasp hands behind back with palms together. straighten arms and rotate arms (inside down) so palm turn downward.
instructions.execution: raise arms away from body. hold stretch.

data.comments: None.

instructions.preparation: face away from wall. bend over and place hands close together as high as possible on wall with fingers positioned upward.
instructions.execution: bring rear end and back toward wall and squat down. hold stretch for 20 seconds.

data.comments: A stationary bar can also be used instead of wall.

instructions.preparation: stand at end of wall or in doorway facing perpendicular to wall. position front of straight arm and palm on surface of wall. situate arm around same height of shoulder with elbow positioned away from wall.
instructions.execution: turn body away from positioned arm. hold stretch. repeat with opposite arm.

data.comments: A stationary bar can also be used instead of wall.

instructions.preparation: placing back of arms on pad with one foot forward, grasp curl bar with shoulder width underhand grip.
instructions.execution: raise bar until forearms are vertical. lower barbell until arms are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Body should be positioned to allow armpit to rest near top of pad. Back of upper arm should remain on pad throughout movement. The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract.

instructions.preparation: sit on preacher bench placing back of arms on pad. grasp curl bar with shoulder width underhand grip.
instructions.execution: raise bar until forearms are vertical. lower barbell until arms are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Seat should be adjusted to allow armpit to rest near top of pad. Back of upper arm should remain on pad throughout movement. The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract. Also known as Scott Curl.

instructions.preparation: lie prone on incline bench with shoulders near top of incline. knees can rest on seat or legs can be straddled to sides. from low rack or partner, grasp curl bar with shoulder width underhand grip.
instructions.execution: raise bar until arms are flexed. lower barbell until arms are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract. Also known as Barbell Spider Curl.

instructions.preparation: facing low pulley cable, sit on seat or bench with legs apart to each side. grasp stirrup attachment. place upper arm against inner thigh.
instructions.execution: pull stirrup to front of shoulder until elbow is completely flexed. lower stirrup until arm is fully extended. repeat. continue with opposite arm.

data.comments: The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract.

instructions.preparation: grasp cable stirrups with each hand. sit on preacher bench placing back of arms on pad with palms up.
instructions.execution: raise one stirrup upward toward shoulder of same arm. lower stirrup until arm is fully extended. repeat with opposite arm. continue alternating between arms.

data.comments: Seat should be adjusted to allowarm pit to rest near top of pad. Back of upper arms should remain on pad throughout movement. The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract. At bottom position, weight stack in use should not make contact with remaining weight stack.

instructions.execution: raise stirrup upward toward shoulder of same arm. lower stirrup until arm is fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Also known as Cable Spider Curl. The long head (lateral head) of biceps brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of biceps brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract. Also known as Cable Spider Curl.

instructions.preparation: sit on bench. grasp dumbbell between feet. place back of upper arm to inner thigh. lean into leg to raise elbow slightly.

instructions.preparation: stand behind incline bench adjusted 45Âº to 55Âº. with dumbbell in hand, arm bent, and palm facing shoulder, place back of arm on pad.
instructions.execution: lower dumbbell until arm is fully extended. raise dumbbell until forearm is vertical. repeat. continue with opposite arm.

data.comments: Dumbbell Preacher Curl can be performed on back of incline bench if preacher bench is not available. However, terminal range of motion will be compromised when thickness of dumbbell does not allow for full extension of elbow.

data.comments: Alternatively, knees can also be placed on seat.Â The long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract.Â Also known as Dumbbell Spider Curl.

instructions.preparation: sit on curl machine. grasp lever handles with underhand grip. align elbows at same pivot point as fulcrum of lever while placing back of arms up on pads.
instructions.execution: pull one lever handle toward shoulder. return handle until arm is fully extended. repeat with opposite arm. continue alternating movement between arms.

data.comments: Back of upper arms should remain on pad throughout movement. If machine has secondary lever (as shown), elbows can be positioned further away from primary fulcrum. Long head (lateral head) of Biceps Brachii is activated significantly more than short head (medial head) of Biceps Brachii since short head enters into active insufficiency as it continues to contract. Long head of Triceps Brachii is only significantly activated as antagonist stabilizer when it approaches passive insufficiency as elbow nears full flexion. See exercise performed with both arms simultaneously.

instructions.preparation: sit on curl machine. grasp lever handles with underhand grip. align elbows at same pivot point as fulcrum of lever while placing back of arms up on pads.
instructions.execution: pull lever handles toward shoulders. return handles until arms are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Back of upper arms should remain on pad throughout movement. If machine has secondary lever (as shown), it is not as essential to position elbows in-line with the primary fulcrum, as would otherwise be required.

instructions.preparation: stand behind arm pad and face lever handles on opposite side. place one foot forward under arm pad and opposite foot back on foot bar. lean over arm pads and grasp handles with slightly narrower than shoulder width underhand grip. squat down and position back of upper arms on arm pads.
instructions.execution: raise lever handles toward shoulders. lower handles until arms are fully extended. repeat.

data.comments: Position armpit to rest near top of pad. Back of upper arm should remain on pad throughout movement. Notice that this machine has secondary lever so elbows are not aligned with primary fulcrum. Also see movement performed with narrow grip. The particular machine shown doubles as Triceps Extension Machine by placing weight on opposite side of fulcrum. Long head of Triceps Brachii is only significantly activated as antagonist stabilizer when it approaches passive insufficiency as elbow nears full flexion.

instructions.preparation: grasp suspension handles and momentarily step back until arms are extended forward and straight. while keeping arms straight and shoulders back, step forward so body is reclined back. position palms up or slightly inward.
instructions.execution: bring handles toward shoulders by flexing arms, while keeping elbows pointed forward. return by straightening arms and repeat.

data.comments: Dismounting can be achieved by walking backward until body is upright. Also known as Suspended Biceps Curl, arguably somewhat of a misnomer. The positioning of arms, with elbows high, places short head (medial head) of Bicep Brachii in active insufficiency as arm continues to flex. The long head of Biceps Brachii (lateral head) and in particular, Brachialis are primary movers in this position.
